docs.snippet: BIG CYPRESS NATIONAL PRESERVE in Florida, 729,000 acres of wetlands and sodden stands of cypress in the Everglades, may not seem to be a likely place for driving through roadless back country. But it has one of the most active off-road-vehicle pro...
docs.lead_paragraph: BIG CYPRESS NATIONAL PRESERVE in Florida, 729,000 acres of wetlands and sodden stands of cypress in the Everglades, may not seem to be a likely place for driving through roadless back country. But it has one of the most active off-road-vehicle programs in the nation, issuing about 2,000 permits a year to drivers of sport utility vehicles, airboats, all-terrain cycles and behemoths known locally as swamp buggies. Swamp buggies, which ride on immense tractor-style tires and can weigh tons, are especially destructive to the soft soils and sensitive vegetation in the swamp, ecologists say. As a result, the National Park Service, which has already closed four areas of the preserve to vehicles, is drafting a new control plan for the park.
docs.abstract: Corresopndent's Report on damage that off-road vehicles have done to sensitive vegetation of Big Cypress National Preserve in Florida, and calls by environmentalists for Park Service to ban such vehicles altogether in nation's parks; environmental groups charge Park Service's proposals for regulating off-road vehicles are not strict enough; 60 organizations have filed petition calling for ban (S)

headline.main: U.S. Parks Face Pressure To Ban Off-Road Vehicles

headline.main: Premier: Trump Ban Doesn't Affect Australia Passport Holders

docs.snippet: FEARS over the safety of air travel in Peru have resurfaced after recent disclosures by Peruvian and American officials that a fatal Aeroperu crash last year was caused by human error and that the United States has banned its Embassy personnel her...
docs.lead_paragraph: FEARS over the safety of air travel in Peru have resurfaced after recent disclosures by Peruvian and American officials that a fatal Aeroperu crash last year was caused by human error and that the United States has banned its Embassy personnel here from flying Aero Continente Airlines. Speaking on condition of anonymity, transportation-safety officials in the United States said that the Embassy's ban on Aero Continente flights and the maintenance errors that caused the Aeroperu crash were compelling reasons for tourists to exercise caution when flying Peruvian airlines, which have suffered a string of major disasters in recent years.
docs.abstract: Fears about safety of air travel in Peru resurface following disclosures that fatal Aeroperu crash in 1996 was caused by maintenance error and that US has banned Embassy personnel from flying Aero Continente Airlines; other cases of poor maintenance, flagrant violations of security and safety also cited; Peru is one of more than 20 nations that fail to meet international aviation safety standards (S)

headline.main: Embassy Ban Rekindles Air-Safety Fears in Peru

docs.snippet: THE contentious issue of snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, which has been debated for at least the past decade, was supposed to have been resolved with a federal ban that was set to start Nov. 15. Just a few months ago, th...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE contentious issue of snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, which has been debated for at least the past decade, was supposed to have been resolved with a federal ban that was set to start Nov. 15. Just a few months ago, the Environmental Protection Agency endorsed the ban, proposed under President Bill Clinton, and the National Park Service was ready to implement it, with the public's blessing. During the public comment period that ended in June, the park service said, it received an unprecedented 361,000 letters and e-mail messages, more than three-fourths of them in support of the ban. But the Bush administration, following a lawsuit by snowmobile manufacturers, blocked it from taking effect.
docs.abstract: National Park Service, following successful lawsuit blocking law banning snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, plans to impose stringent standards that would force manufacturers to produce cleaner and quieter machines they have long promised; map (M)

headline.main: Snowmobiles in Parks: Limits, but Not a Ban
